International A3-15
The U.S.-Canadian trade agreement, expected to take effect Jan. 1, will formalize the largest economic partnership of two countries, signaling vast changes in world trade. Page A1
Canadian approval of a trade pact with the United States will be sought ''at the first opportunity,'' Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said. He won parliamentary majority in Monday's election. A12

Man in the news: Brian Mulroney, the first Canadian Prime Minister to rise from the working class, used confidence to battle for his office and for a free-trade pact. ''We don't fear competition!'' he would shout. A1
South Korea's former President, Chun Doo Hwan, apologized to the nation for abuses during his eight years as President and said he stood ready to face punishment. A1
South Africa accepts the terms of a package for peace in southwestern Africa, the nation's Foreign Minister announced. A13
Israel's Labor Party broke off talks with its rival, the Likud party, on forming a broad coalition, saying the negotiations were useless. A14

Latvia did not declare sovereignty in a vote by its legislature, apparently giving the Kremlin another success in its efforts to blunt the Baltic republics' opposition to proposed constitutional changes. A3
Kabul journal: Boys fly kites, men fire shells A4
Indictment of a magistrate stirs political furor in France A5
U.S. making Arafat go through all the steps for a visa A14

President-elect Bush said the budget will get his 'hands on' involvement as President. On his first day in office, Mr. Bush said, he will name negotiators to work with Congress in reducing the budget deficit. A1
Consumer prices rose by four-tenths of 1 percent in October, the Government reported. It was the seventh straight month in which prices rose by either three-tenths or four-tenths of 1 percent. D1
The U.S. agreed to a nuclear clean up at uranium plant in Ohio that is vital to the operation of nuclear submarines and to civilian reactors around the country. A1
A restructuring of airline fares, one of the most extensive in a decade, went into effect, substantially raising the cost of flying for business and leisure travelers on most routes. A1
The ''stealth'' bomber was displayed in public for the first time, its gray and black nose exposed to a crowd of cameramen and congressmen in a special enclosure within a top-secret compound. D19
President-elect Bush met Mexico's incoming President Carlos Salinas de Gortari in Houston. He also brushed aside news reports that he favored former Senator John Tower as Secretary of Defense. D20

Bush aides are recruiting blacks for Administration posts, though few are readily available from the Bush campaign. A lot of women worked in the campaign, and aides say many will get top high-level jobs. D20

Blacks face more likely segregation when they move to suburbs than Hispanic and Asian people, a University of Chicago study says. The report concludes that there were ''strong penalties for being black.'' A16

A series of billion-dollar deals on Wall Street has renewed calls for sweeping changes in the tax code to discourage borrowing for takeovers. Experts say that changing the rules is no simple matter. D1
Quietly, the country mourns J.F.K. A16
Rumors fly as Bush sets return to summer home A16

Washington Talk B5
Will Ronald Reagan issue pardons to Oliver North and John Poindexter, the former White House aides who have been indicted for their role in the Iran-contra affair? Time is running out. Regional B1-4
New York City buys concrete for $10 more a cubic yard than private companies charge, the result of having helped set up a company that it had hoped would bring down prices industrywide. A1

Bronx school board members are being investigated on charges of drug use and theft of school equipment, a law-enforcement official said. It is the board that administers the elementary school whose principal was recently arrested on a drug-possession charge. B1

Mayor Koch testified in the trial of Bess Myerson, saying he had ''no recollection'' of discussing Ms. Myerson with one of his special assistants in October 1983. Earlier, the assistant said he had discussed her with the Mayor. B1 People who live in mobile homes in the suburbs of New York City and the rural areas just beyond are being squeezed out as mobile home park owners sell their land to developers. Many have nowhere else to go. B1
Bernhard Goetz's conviction on an illegal weapons charge was unanimously upheld by New York State's highest court, clearing the way for his sentencing on the charge. B3

New York City's disposal of garbage is likely to be affected by the refusal of the state's Environmental Commissioner to grant an incinerator permit until the city acts to improve recycling and disposal plans. B3
